cleaned_text: Acting through the VDR, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is a potent immune system modulator. The VDR is expressed by most cells of the immune system, including regulatory T cells and [antigen](../glossary#antigen)-presenting cells, such as [dendritic cells](../glossary#dendritic-cell) and [macrophages](../glossary#macrophage) [(9)](#reference9). Under specific circumstances, [monocytes](../glossary#monocyte), T cells can express the 25-hydroxyvitamin D3-1-hydroxylase [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) and produce 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, which acts locally to regulate the immune response [(10, 11)](#reference10). There is considerable scientific evidence that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D has a variety of effects on immune system function, which may enhance [innate immunity](../health-disease/immunity#innate-immunity) and inhibit the development of [autoimmunity](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) [(12)](#reference12). Conversely, vitamin D deficiency may compromise the integrity of the immune system and lead to inappropriate immune responses (see [Autoimmune diseases](#autoimmune-diseases-prevention)). The renin-angiotensin system plays an important role in the regulation of blood pressure [(16)](#reference16). Renin is an [enzyme](../glossary#enzyme) that [catalyzes](../glossary#catalyst) the cleavage (splitting) of a small [peptide](../glossary#peptide) (angiotensin I) from a larger [protein](../glossary#protein) (angiotensinogen) produced in liver. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) catalyzes the cleavage of angiotensin I to form angiotensin II, a peptide that can increase blood pressure by inducing the constriction of small arteries and by increasing [sodium](../minerals/sodium) and water retention. The rate of angiotensin II [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) is dependent on renin [(17)](#reference17). Research in mice lacking the [gene](../glossary#gene) encoding the VDR indicates that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D decreases the [expression](../glossary#gene-expression) of the gene encoding renin through its interaction with the VDR [(18)](#reference18). Since inappropriate activation of the renin-angiotensin system can contribute to the development of [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), achieving adequate vitamin D status may be important for decreasing the [risk](../glossary#risk) of high blood pressure (see [Hypertension](#hypertension-prevention)). In infants and children, severe vitamin D deficiency results in the failure of bone to mineralize. The process of mineralization, which involves the production of crystals of calcium phosphate by bone-forming cells, determines the hardness and strength of bones. Vitamin D deficiency severely affects rapidly growing bones. The growth plates of bones continue to enlarge, but in the absence of adequate mineralization, weight-bearing limbs (arms and legs) become bowed. In infants, [rickets](../glossary#rickets) may result in delayed closure of the fontanels (soft spots) in the skull, and the rib cage may become deformed due to the pulling action of the diaphragm. In severe cases, low [serum](../glossary#serum) calcium concentrations (hypocalcemia) may cause [seizures](../glossary#seizure). Although [fortification](../glossary#fortification) of food has led to complacency regarding vitamin D deficiency, nutritional rickets is still being reported throughout the world [(19, 20)](#reference19). Although adult bones are no longer growing, they are in a constant state of turnover, or " [remodeling](../glossary#bone-remodeling)." In adults with severe vitamin D deficiency, the [collagenous bone matrix](../glossary#collagenous-matrix) is preserved, but bone mineral is progressively lost, resulting in a softening of bones ( [osteomalacia](../glossary#osteomalacia)), bone pain, and increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) [(21)](#reference21). Vitamin D deficiency causes muscle weakness and pain in children and adults. Muscle pain and weakness were prominent symptoms of vitamin D deficiency in a study of Arab and Danish Muslim women living in Denmark [(22)](#reference22). In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 150 consecutive patients referred to a clinic in Minnesota for the evaluation of persistent, nonspecific musculoskeletal pain, 93% had [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations equal to or below 20 ng/mL, with a mean concentration of 12.1 ng/mL, which is indicative of vitamin D insufficiency [(23)](#reference23). Loss of muscle strength greatly contributes to increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of falling and bone [fractures](../glossary#fracture), especially in older people [(24)](#reference24). In addition, long-term vitamin D insufficiency may be a contributing factor to [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) in the elderly (see [Osteoporosis](#osteoporosis-prevention)). Both environmental factors and cultural practices result in variations in vitamin D status: Growing awareness that vitamin D insufficiency has serious health consequences beyond [rickets](../glossary#rickets) and [osteomalacia](../glossary#osteomalacia) highlights the need for accurate assessment of vitamin D nutritional status. It is currently agreed that the measurement of total [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration (1 ng/mL corresponding to 2.5 nmol/L) is the best indicator to evaluate vitamin D status. However, high-quality evidence is still needed to ensure that the current cutoff values are optimal to define states of insufficiency and deficiency [(40)](#reference40). Moreover, only recently, efforts have been made toward the standardization of commercially and laboratory-developed 25-hydroxyvitamin D assays, such that guidelines have been developed using largely unstandardized research data [(49)](#reference49). Although laboratory reference values for sufficient vitamin D status were initially based on serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations from cohorts of healthy individuals, additional studies have suggested that health-based cutoff values aimed at preventing secondary [hyperparathyroidism](../glossary#hyperparathyroidism) and bone loss should be considerably higher. Indeed, while it is considered that serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations less than 8 to 10 ng/mL (20 to 25 nmol/L) indicate severe deficiency associated with rickets and osteomalacia, several studies have observed that PTH concentrations [(50, 51)](#reference50) and [calcium](../minerals/calcium) absorption [(52)](#reference52) were not optimized with serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations below 32 ng/mL (80 nmol/L). Yet, more recent studies have failed to find threshold values of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations in relation to PTH suppression and optimal calcium absorption. On the one hand, a [cross-sectional analysis](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) of 312,962 clinical samples did not find any evidence of threshold for PTH suppression in the well-fitted curve displaying the [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between paired measurements of serum PTH and 25-hydroxyvitamin D, even with 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations beyond 70 ng/mL (175 nmol/L) [(53)](#reference53). This contradicted an analysis of the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES 2003-2006) that estimated maximum PTH suppression for 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of 40 ng/mL (100 nmol/L) and above [(54)](#reference54). In addition, both studies identified evidence of mild hyperparathyroidism (serum PTH >65 pg/mL) in individuals with serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations well beyond 20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L), questioning the use of serum PTH as a sensible indicator of vitamin D insufficiency [(53, 54)](#reference53). On the other hand, a randomized, placebo-controlled in postmenopausal women D <20 ng/mL) supplemented with daily vitamin D3 doses from 400 to 4,800 IU found little change (6%) in calcium absorption over a normal 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration range of 20 to 66 ng/mL [(55)](#reference55). The current cutoffs proposed by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows: deficiency as serum D 12 to 19 ng/mL (30 to 49 nmol/L), and sufficiency as serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values of 20 to 50 ng/mL (50 to 125 nmol/L) [(56)](#reference56). The dietary reference intakes ( [EAR](../glossary#EAR), [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) set by the IOM are based on achieving circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (20 to 50 ng/mL) that are adequate to maintain bone health and optimal calcium absorption [(57)](#reference57). Yet, considering the potential role of circulating concentrations lower than 30 ng/mL in the burden of many chronic diseases [(6)](#reference6), the US Endocrine Society has suggested to define cutoff values as follows: deficiency as serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values 20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L), insufficiency as serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values of 21 to 29 ng/mL (51 to 74 nmol/L), and sufficiency as serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values of 30 to 100 ng/mL (75 to 250 nmol/L) [(40)](#reference40). This alternate target range is supported by some [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study), but it is not based on data from [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) (see [Disease Prevention](#disease-prevention)) [(47)](#reference47). With these latter cutoff values, studies from across the world have estimated that hypovitaminosis D is widespread and that children and adults of all ages are equally at [risk](../glossary#risk) of insufficiency and deficiency [(58)](#reference58). Data from supplementation studies indicate that vitamin D intakes of at least 800 to 1,000 IU/day are required by adults living in temperate latitudes to achieve serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of at least 30 ng/mL (75 nmol/L) [(40)](#reference40). Finally, total serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations may not always adequately reflect vitamin D [bioavailability](../glossary#bioavailability) [(59)](#reference59), and additional evidence is needed to improve the determination of vitamin D status in different ethnic populations. In 2010, the Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) of the IOM set a Recommended Dietary Allowance ( [RDA](../glossary#RDA)) based on the amount of vitamin D needed for bone health. While the RDA was increased from the adequate intake (AI) set in 1997, the optimal levels of recommended intakes and [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D to minimize [hyperthyroidism](../glossary#hyperthyroidism) and maximize bone health in the general population remain controversial [(40)](#reference40). Osteoporosis Vitamin D status, osteoporosis, and risk of fracture Although the causes of [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) are [multifactorial](../glossary#multifactorial), vitamin D insufficiency can be an important [etiological](../glossary#etiology) factor in older adults. Osteoporosis affects one-third of women aged 60 to 70 years and two-thirds of women aged 80 years and above [(66)](#reference66). A multinational (18 different countries with latitudes ranging from 64 degrees north to 38 degrees south) survey of more than 2,600 postmenopausal women with osteoporosis revealed that 31% of subjects had 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L) [(67)](#reference67). In addition, a [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) that included 111 hip [fracture](../glossary#fracture) patients and 73 controls (median age, 83 years) found that lower serum concentrations of both 25-hydroxyvitamin D and vitamin K1 in patients compared to controls were associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of hip fracture [(68)](#reference68). Without sufficient vitamin D from sun exposure or dietary intake, intestinal calcium absorption can be significantly reduced. This increases PTH secretion by the [parathyroid glands](../glossary#parathyroid-glands); sustained PTH elevation may result in increased [bone resorption](../glossary#bone-resorption), which in turn may increase the risk of osteoporotic fracture [(69)](#reference69). Vitamin D supplementation and bone mineral density The progressive loss of [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) (BMD) leading to [osteopenia](../glossary#osteopenia) (pre-osteoporosis) and [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) is commonly observed in older adults, especially the elderly. The results of a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 23 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) with more than 4,000 participants (mean age, 59 years) showed little evidence for an effect of vitamin D supplementation on BMD at any of the five skeletal sites examined, including lumbar spine, femoral neck, trochanter, forearm, and total body. A significant increase in BMD was reported only at the femoral neck [(70)](#reference70). It was, however, suggested that individuals in this age group would have adequate calcium intake and thus normal bone [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism), explaining the lack of an effect of vitamin D in strengthening bone mass [(71)](#reference71). Conversely, in older individuals, vitamin D supplementation is essential to correct and maintain adequate concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D and to prevent secondary [hyperparathyroidism](../glossary#hyperparathyroidism) and BMD loss [(72)](#reference72). Vitamin D supplementation and risk of fracture A [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed more than 72,000 postmenopausal women in the US for 18 years found that those who consumed at least 600 IU/day of vitamin D from diet and [supplements](../glossary#supplement) had a 37% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of [osteoporotic](../glossary#osteoporosis) hip [fracture](../glossary#fracture) than women who consumed less than 140 IU/day of vitamin D [(73)](#reference73). However, daily supplementation with 400 IU of vitamin D3, in combination with 1,000 mg calcium, did not significantly reduce risk of hip fracture compared to a [placebo](../glossary#placebo) in 36,282 postmenopausal women from the Women's Health Initiative trial [(74)](#reference74), suggesting that there might be a threshold of vitamin D intake that is necessary to observe reductions in fracture risk. Results of a genetic analysis of data from this trial also suggested that beneficial effects of vitamin D and calcium supplementation on fracture risk might be limited to women with the lowest genetic risk of low [BMD](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) [(75)](#reference75). Yet, this trial has been questioned for reasons that include poor adherence and the fact that participants were allowed to take additional vitamin D and calcium supplements that might have [confounded](../glossary#confounder) the results. In addition, use of hormone replacement therapy was not considered in the study of the effect of vitamin D and calcium on skeletal health in postmenopausal women despite being a major confounding factor in this population [(57](#reference57), [76)](#reference76). Another trial, the Randomised Evaluation of Calcium Or vitamin D (RECORD) study, reported that oral supplemental vitamin D3 (800 IU/day) alone, or in combination with calcium (1,000 mg/day), did not prevent the occurrence of osteoporotic fractures in elderly adults who had already experienced a low-trauma, osteoporotic fracture [(77)](#reference77). In this latter study as well, a number of limitations, including poor adherence and/or the fact that vitamin D supplementation did not raise serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations to a level that would protect against fractures, might explain the lack of an effect [(78)](#reference78). Despite high adherence to treatment, the incidence of non-vertebral fracture was similar in postmenopausal women supplemented with vitamin D3 (initial dose of 200,000 IU followed by 100,000/month) or placebo for over three years in the Vitamin D Assessment (ViDA) trial [(79)](#reference79). Nevertheless, the US Preventive Services Task Force that conducted the [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 11 [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), placebo-controlled trials, including 52,915 older people (of whom 69% were postmenopausal women), found that the supplementation of vitamin D (300-1,000 IU/day) and calcium (500-1,200 mg/day) for up to seven years resulted in a 12% reduction in the risk of any new fracture [(80)](#reference80). Another meta-analysis of 11 randomized, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), placebo-controlled trials on the effect of vitamin D supplementation in 31,022 individuals (91% women) 65 years and older indicated that those with the highest vitamin D intake (792-2,000 IU/day) had a 30% lower risk of hip fracture and a 14% lower risk of any non-spine fracture [(81)](#reference81). Finally, a third meta-analysis of trials that examined the effect of combined vitamin D and calcium in preventing fractures in older men and postmenopausal women also concluded that the risk of new fractures, including hip fractures, was significantly reduced in those supplemented compared to controls [(82)](#reference82). Interestingly, the three meta-analyses have found that the prevention of fractures by supplemental vitamin D and calcium was limited to institutionalized, older people. Indeed, the risk of fracture was not significantly reduced by vitamin D in community-dwelling seniors [(80-82)](#reference80). Vitamin D supplementation and postural balance, muscle strength, and risk of fall A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) in 840 fallers and 1,330 found significantly 25-hydroxyvitamin D in fallers than in non-fallers [(83)](#reference83). Moreover, another meta-analysis of four cohorts from three observational studies reported a modest yet significant [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between vitamin D status and the [risk](../glossary#risk) of fall [(83)](#reference83). Several [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined the impact of vitamin D supplementation on muscle strength, postural balance, or risk of fall in older subjects. A meta-analysis of these trials found limited evidence of an effect of vitamin D supplementation on muscle strength and mobility, based on only one type of test for each outcome. Nevertheless, in a recent [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 160 postmenopausal women (ages, 50-65 years) with suboptimal vitamin D status (mean serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration <20 ng/mL), supplementation with 1,000 IU/day of vitamin D3 significantly improved vitamin D status, as well as upper and lower limb muscle strength and postural balance parameters [(84, 85)](#reference84). The risks of fall and recurrent falls were found to be two- to three-fold greater in women in the control group than in those supplemented with vitamin D3 [(85)](#reference85). In contrast, another 12-month randomized controlled study in 200 older adults (of which 58% had a baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration <20 ng/mL) showed no benefits regarding lower extremity function or odds of falling in those supplemented with 2,000 IU/day (+/- 10 µg of calcidiol) compared to those who received 800 IU/day [(86)](#reference86). The recently published post-hoc analysis of the ViDA trial found no differences in odds of falling and number of falls reported by 5,108 community-dwelling participants (ages, 50-84 years) regardless of whether they were randomized to receive supplemental vitamin D (100,000 IU/month, i.e. ~3,350 IU/day) or a placebo for a mean 3.4 years [(79)](#reference79). Most ViDA participants had serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations 20 ng/mL, which might at least partly explain the lack of an effect of vitamin D on falls [(87)](#reference87). Overall, the current evidence suggests that vitamin D3 supplements of 800-1,000 IU/day may be helpful in reducing falls and fracture rates in older adults. In order for vitamin D supplementation to be effective in preserving bone health, adequate dietary calcium (1,000 to 1,200 mg/day) should be consumed (see the article on [Calcium](../minerals/calcium)) [(88)](#reference88). Cancer [Ecologic studies](../glossary#ecologic-study) first suggested an association between Northern latitudes, vitamin D deficiency, and [cancer](../glossary#cancer) incidence [(89)](#reference89). Since the 1980s, several [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have examined the association of vitamin D intake or status and various types of cancer. A 2013 [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 16 prospective studies, including 137,567 subjects, reported an 11% reduction in total cancer incidence and a 17% reduction in cancer mortality with each 20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L) increase in circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations. Yet, a sex-based subgroup analysis of eight studies found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between circulating vitamin D and cancer mortality in women, but not in men [(90)](#reference90). In addition, increasing evidence suggests that a few variations in the [gene](../glossary#gene) coding for the vitamin D [receptor](../glossary#receptor) (VDR) might influence individual vitamin D status and subsequently modify the susceptibility to site-specific cancers [(91)](#reference91) and influence cancer survival [(92)](#reference92). Finally, many [malignant](../glossary#malignant) tumors have been found to express the VDR, including breast, lung, skin (melanoma), [colon](../glossary#colon), and bone [(93)](#reference93), suggesting that they might be susceptible to the effects of vitamin D. Numerous experimental studies have demonstrated that biologically active forms of vitamin D, such as 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D and its [analogs](../glossary#analog), upon binding to the VDR, can control cell fate by inhibiting [proliferation](../glossary#proliferation) and/or inducing cell [differentiation](../glossary#differentiation) or death ( [apoptosis](../glossary#apoptosis)) of a number of cancerous cell types [(94)](#reference94). Colorectal cancer The geographic distribution of [colon](../glossary#colon) [cancer](../glossary#cancer) mortality resembles the historical geographic distribution of [rickets](../glossary#rickets) [(95)](#reference95), providing circumstantial evidence that decreased sunlight exposure and diminished vitamin D nutritional status may be related to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of colon cancer. Evidence from observational studies has largely supported this hypothesis. A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), four [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between circulating vitamin D and incidence of [colorectal adenoma](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma) — a benign tumor that may transform to become [malignant](../glossary#malignant) [(96)](#reference96). The analysis identified a 32% risk reduction between top versus bottom quantiles of [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations [(96)](#reference96). Additionally, there is strong evidence from meta-analyses of prospective cohort studies to suggest that higher vitamin D intakes and serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations are associated with reductions in colorectal cancer risk [(97-99)](#reference97). The most recent meta-analysis of four prospective cohort, 17 [nested case-control](../glossary#nested-case-control-study), and three case-control studies found a 38% reduced risk of colorectal cancer with high versus low quantiles of circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations [(100)](#reference100). A dose-response analysis estimated that serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of ~20 to 30 ng/mL (compared to 12 ng/mL) were associated with a 17% lower risk of colorectal cancer, and the risk was even lower (-35%) with a serum concentration of 55 ng/mL [(100)](#reference100). An earlier dose-response analysis based on five nested case-control studies had estimated that serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations 33 ng/mL (compared to 12 ng/mL) were associated with a 50% lower risk of colorectal cancer [(101)](#reference101). However, in a seven-year, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 36,282 postmenopausal women participating in the Women's Health Initiative study, a combination of supplemental vitamin D3 (400 IU/day) and calcium (1,000 mg/day) did not lower incidence of colorectal cancer [(102)](#reference102). Another [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of vitamin D3 (1,000 IU/day), with or without calcium supplementation (1,200 mg/day), found no reduction in the risk of colorectal adenoma recurrence over a three-to-five year period, compared to placebo, after initial adenoma removal in participants [(103)](#reference103). Whether these daily vitamin D doses are too low to detect any effect on cancer incidence is not clear [(101, 104)](#reference101). Additional randomized [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) are needed to assess whether vitamin D supplementation could help prevent colorectal cancer. Moreover, it is uncertain whether genetic variations ( [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism)) in the sequence of [genes](../glossary#gene) involved in vitamin D [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and function can influence the relationship between vitamin D status and risk of colorectal adenoma or colorectal cancer [(105-107)](#reference105). Finally, growing evidence suggests that adequate vitamin D status may be linked to better survival of colorectal cancer patients. A meta-analysis of five prospective studies found a 35% reduced risk of colorectal cancer-specific mortality in cancer patients with higher serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations. A dose-response analysis estimated that every 8 ng/mL increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was associated with a 10% decrease in colorectal cancer mortality [(108)](#reference108). Breast cancer Although [ecologic](../glossary#ecologic-study) evidence suggests that breast [cancer](../glossary#cancer) mortality rises with increasing latitudes and decreasing sunlight exposure [(109)](#reference109), the most current [observational](../glossary#observational-study) data provide little support for an association between vitamin D nutritional status and risk of breast cancer. An early [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of women who participated in the First US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES I) found that Caucasian women with adequate sunlight exposure and dietary vitamin D intake had a significantly reduced risk of breast cancer 20 years later [(110)](#reference110). Nonetheless, when this study was included in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) with nine more recent prospective studies, there was no significant difference in the risk of developing breast cancer between the highest and lowest levels of vitamin D intakes [(111)](#reference111). Moreover, whether an association exists between circulating vitamin D concentrations and risk of breast cancer is unclear. One meta-analysis of 14 observational studies (9,110 cases and 16,244 controls) reported an overall risk reduction of 16% when the highest quantile of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations was compared to the lowest. This [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) was statistically significant in postmenopausal women but not in premenopausal women [(112)](#reference112). Yet, another meta-analysis that included a similar set of 14 prospective studies (two studies were different) found no overall association [(111)](#reference111). Additionally, a meta-analysis of studies conducted in patients in the early stage of breast cancer identified associations between inadequate vitamin D status and increased risks of recurrence and death [(113)](#reference113). Evidence from [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) is currently too limited to conclude whether vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) may reduce breast cancer incidence (reviewed in [114](#reference114)). Nonetheless, three meta-analyses have found an inverse association between circulating vitamin D concentrations and breast cancer-related mortality [(111](#reference111), [115, 116)](#reference115). In one meta-analysis of one [retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) and five prospective cohort studies, the highest versus lowest categories of serum vitamin D concentrations was associated with a 33% reduction in mortality; a dose-response analysis found a 12% reduction per 8 ng/mL increase in serum vitamin D [(115)](#reference115). Finally, current evidence does not suggest that specific genetic variations in the [gene](../glossary#gene) coding for the VDR may influence the risk of breast cancer [(117, 118)](#reference117). Other types of cancer Evidence associating vitamin D status with other types of [cancer](../glossary#cancer) is currently limited. While incidence of [prostate](../glossary#prostate) cancer appears to be [inversely associated](../glossary#inverse-association) with the availability of sunlight, [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) have not generally found significant relationships between [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and subsequent [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing prostate cancer [(119, 120)](#reference119). In fact, some studies have suggested an increased risk of prostate cancer with higher circulating vitamin D concentrations. For example, a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) of men (622 cases and 1,451 controls) from Scandinavia found a U-shaped relationship between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and prostate cancer risk. In that study, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of 7.6 ng/mL or lower, or 32 ng/mL or higher, were associated with increased prostate cancer risk [(121)](#reference121). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 17 nested case-control studies, three prospective cohort studies, and one retrospective cohort study found a 17% increased risk of prostate cancer in individuals in the highest versus lowest categories of blood 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations [(122)](#reference122). Potential [confounding](../glossary#confounder) factors that might explain the detection of a slight increase in prostate cancer cases in men with high circulating vitamin D concentrations have been highlighted in a recent publication [(123)](#reference123). Finally, recent meta-analyses of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found an inverse relationship between vitamin D status and risk of lung cancer [(124, 125)](#reference124) and bladder cancer [(126, 127)](#reference126). Yet, in the few and often [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneity) studies published to date, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations were not associated with other cancer types, including non-Hodgkin's lymphoma [(128)](#reference128), ovarian cancer [(129)](#reference129), [gastric](../glossary#gastric) are examples of [autoimmune diseases](../glossary#autoimmune-disease). Autoimmune diseases occur when the body mounts an immune response against its own tissue, rather than a foreign [pathogen](../glossary#pathogen). In type 1 diabetes mellitus, insulin-producing -cells of the [pancreas](../glossary#pancreas) are the target of an inappropriate immune response. In MS, the targets are the [myelin](../glossary#myelin)-producing cells of the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system), and in RA, the targets are the [collagen](../glossary#collagen)-producing cells of the joints [(132)](#reference132). SLE is characterized by the presence of a large spectrum of autoantibodies resulting in potential damage to multiple tissues [(133)](#reference133). Autoimmune responses are mediated by immune cells called T cells. The biologically active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, has been found to modulate T cell responses, such that the autoimmune responses are diminished. [Ecologic studies](../glossary#ecologic-study) have found that the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of autoimmune diseases (particularly for MS; [134](#reference134)) increases as latitude increases, suggesting that lower exposure to UVB radiation and associated decreases in skin vitamin D [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) may play a role in the [pathology](../glossary#pathology) of these diseases. Results of several [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) also suggest that adequate vitamin D status at different ages (including in utero, early childhood, and during adolescence) could possibly decrease the [risk](../glossary#risk) of autoimmune diseases. Type 1 diabetes mellitus Lower levels of circulating vitamin D have been reported in patients newly diagnosed with type 1 [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) compared to age- and sex-matched non-diabetic A greater [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of vitamin D insufficiency and deficiency has also been observed in prediabetic children who developed multiple islet autoantibodies (antibodies against [insulin](../glossary#insulin)-secreting [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) cells) compared to autoantibody-negative children. However, a [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) that followed the cohort of prediabetic children found that their vitamin D status, defined as either insufficient, deficient, or sufficient, was not associated with rate of progression to type 1 diabetes after 5 or 10 years of follow up [(137)](#reference137). An earlier prospective cohort study of children born in Finland during the year 1966 and followed for 30 years found that children supplemented with vitamin D during the first year of life had an 88% lower [risk](../glossary#risk) of developing type 1 diabetes compared to those receiving no supplementation. Moreover, children suspected of having had [rickets](../glossary#rickets) (severe vitamin D deficiency) during the first year of life showed a significantly higher risk of developing type 1 diabetes [(138)](#reference138). Thus, vitamin D supplementation appears protective against type 1 diabetes onset, and suboptimal vitamin D status in infancy may have long-term effects on immune responses later in life. There are also limited data suggesting that maternal vitamin D insufficiency during pregnancy may influence the risk of type 1 diabetes in offspring. In a recent [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study), the risk of childhood onset of type 1 diabetes was more than two-fold greater in children whose mothers had [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <21.6 ng/mL (54 nmol/L) during the last trimester of pregnancy compared to children born from women with serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D >35.6 ng/mL (89 nmol/L) [(139)](#reference139). Other case-control studies have found that vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy was associated with a lower risk of their children developing diabetes-related autoantibodies [(140, 141)](#reference140). However, a larger study conducted in mothers of children at increased genetic risk for diabetes reported no association between the appearance of islet autoantibodies and/or diabetes onset in offspring in the first year of life and maternal vitamin D intake during pregnancy [(142)](#reference142). Another case-control study failed to observe a relationship between serum 25-dihydroxyvitamin D during early pregnancy and type 1 diabetes diagnosis in offspring [(143)](#reference143). Large prospective studies are needed to establish whether maternal vitamin D status during pregnancy can influence the risk of type 1 diabetes in offspring. Finally, the relationship of [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in vitamin D [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism)-related [genes](../glossary#gene) and type 1 diabetes is currently under investigation. It has been proposed that specific polymorphisms in genes, such as CYP27B1 (coding for 25-hydroxyvitamin D3-1-hydroxylase) and VDR, may be functionally relevant to the action of vitamin D and may thus affect disease susceptibility. In a study conducted in 8,517 children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes and 7,320 control subjects, polymorphisms in genes involved in [cholesterol](../glossary#cholesterol) [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) and vitamin D [hydroxylation](../glossary#hydroxylation) were linked to circulating vitamin D concentrations and diabetic status [(26)](#reference26). Multiple sclerosis Low levels of sun exposure and vitamin D deficiency appear to be associated with the development of [multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) (MS). Poor vitamin D status may compromise the function of specific immune cells critical in the regulation of various immune responses and help trigger autoimmunity in MS [(144)](#reference144). Genetic determinants of low vitamin D status have been recently linked to an increased susceptibility to adult-onset MS in a [Mendelian randomization analysis](../glossary#Mendelian-randomization-study) of data from the Multiple Sclerosis Genetics Consortium [(145)](#reference145). This echoed the results of several [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that suggested an association between vitamin D sufficiency and decreased MS [risk](../glossary#risk). A [retrospective study](../glossary#retrospective-study) of levels of ambient UV radiation and cases of MS conducted in Australia revealed that MS incidence in offspring was [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) to maternal exposure to UV during early pregnancy [(146)](#reference146). Sun exposure was also used as a surrogate marker for vitamin D exposure in a recent [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) that included 1,660 MS patients and 3,050 controls. The authors found that infrequent outdoor activities and the use of sunscreen during early childhood and adolescence were associated with an increased risk of developing MS later in life [(147)](#reference147). In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study), sun exposure and intake of cod liver oil (rich in vitamin D) during childhood were linked to later symptom onset among veterans with relapsing MS [(148)](#reference148). Additionally, a case-control study in US military personnel, including 257 cases of diagnosed MS, found that Caucasian subjects in the highest [quintile](../glossary#quintile) of [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D (>39.6 ng/mL) had a 62% lower risk of developing MS compared to the lowest quintile (<25.3 ng/mL) (149). Further, in two large cohorts of over 187,000 US women followed for at least 10 years, vitamin D [supplement](../glossary#supplement) use (400 IU/day) was associated with a 41% reduction in the risk of developing MS [(150)](#reference150). Another prospective, uncontrolled study monitored incidence of relapse in relation to vitamin D status in 156 patients with relapsing-remitting MS before and after they were given supplemental vitamin D (100,000 IU/month; 6-42 months, median of 31 months), in addition to first-line immunomodulatory therapy [(151)](#reference151). Each 4 ng/mL increase in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was associated with a 14.9% decrease in incidence of relapse [(151)](#reference151). In a multicenter study conducted in patients newly diagnosed with a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) and treated with interferon (IFN)-, vitamin D status was predictive of MS disease activity and progression. Higher serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (20 ng/mL or 50 nmol/L) in the first year following CIS diagnosis predicted a longer time to MS diagnosis, lower number of new lesions, and lower changes in lesion and brain volume during the subsequent four years of follow-up [(152)](#reference152). However, a retrospective study suggested that vitamin D status in patients with relapsing-remitting MS had no predictive value regarding the time to conversion to secondary progressive MS, which is characterized by a worsening of disability [(153)](#reference153). [Clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) have failed to demonstrate any benefit of vitamin D supplementation, alone or in combination with IFN- treatment, with respect to relapse rates and disability-related symptoms in MS patients [(154, 155)](#reference154). In other trials, supplemental vitamin D3 also failed to demonstrate immunomodulary activities [(156-159)](#reference156). In a recent randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 53 IFN--treated patients with relapsing-remitting MS, supplementation with vitamin D3 (7,000 IU/day for four weeks, followed by 14,000 IU/day until week 48) showed little effect on the proportion of some regulatory T and B [lymphocytes](../glossary#lymphocyte) over the 48-week study period. Vitamin D3 only appeared to help maintain the proportion of anti-inflammatory CD4+ T cells — which decreased in patients given placebo — but failed to enhance their reactivity when stimulated with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [in vitro](../glossary#in-vitro) trial, supplementation with vitamin D3 (10,400 IU/day for three months) to patients with relapsing-remitting MS was found to reduce the proportion of pro-inflammatory IL-17-producing CD4+ T cells, which are thought to play a central role in MS development [(160)](#reference160). Rheumatoid arthritis Vitamin D deficiency may also be implicated in the [etiology](../glossary#etiology) and/or progression of [rheumatoid arthritis](../glossary#rheumatoid-arthritis) (RA), although evidence is mainly from animal studies. The absence of vitamin D [receptors](../glossary#receptor) (VDR) in genetically modified mice has been linked to higher levels of [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation) and increased susceptibility to [autoimmunity](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) [(161)](#reference161). When transgenic mice that spontaneously develop inflammatory arthritis are also deficient in VDR, they develop a more aggressive form of chronic arthritis [(162)](#reference162). Also, specific [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) in the VDR [gene](../glossary#gene) have been linked to an increased susceptibility to RA in certain populations, although how these genetic variants influence vitamin D functionality is not fully understood [(163-165)](#reference163). The current data, however, point to a role for vitamin D in modulating the inflammatory process that underlies many [chronic diseases](../glossary#chronic-disease), including RA. Several [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in individuals with moderate-to-high levels of inflammation have reported either no association or an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration and markers of inflammation. Nonetheless, there is a lack of [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) to show whether vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) could limit inflammation and reduce disease [risk](../glossary#risk) (including RA) in subjects with high inflammation levels [(166)](#reference166). At this time, it remains unclear whether the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of vitamin D deficiency is linked to RA incidence. In a large cohort study of nearly 30,000 postmenopausal US women, subjects with the highest total vitamin D intakes (467.7 IU/day) had a 33% lower risk of developing RA after 11 years of follow-up than those with the lowest intakes (<221.4 IU/day) [(167)](#reference167). Yet, more recent analyses of two large cohorts of nearly 200,000 US women followed for several decades found no association between reported vitamin D dietary intakes (using [food frequency questionnaires](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire)) during adolescence or adulthood and incidence of RA later in life [(168, 169)](#reference168). Moreover, several studies that explored the relationship between circulating vitamin D and disease activity in RA patients have reported mixed results (reviewed in [170](#reference170)). Yet, two recent meta-analyses of observational studies found an inverse relationship between vitamin D status and disease activity in RA patients, assessed using the Disease Activity Score 28 ( [DAS28](http://www.nras.org.uk/the-das28-score)) [(171, 172)](#reference171). Finally, there is a dearth of studies exploring the effect of vitamin D supplementation on disease activity in arthritis subjects. A small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 22 RA patients failed to demonstrate improvements in disease activity and inflammation level in subjects supplemented with [calcium](../minerals/calcium) (1,500 mg/day) and high doses of vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol; averaging over 4,500 IU/day) for a year compared to placebo [(173)](#reference173). Another three-month, randomized controlled trial in 41 women with early RA found no additional benefits of supplemental vitamin D3 (one bolus dose of 300,000 IU) to standard care (methotrexate and glucocorticoids) regarding T-helper lymphocyte enumeration, cytokine production, or clinical parameters including disease activity [(174)](#reference174). Supplemental vitamin D also failed to reduce disease recurrence rate in RA patients enrolled in two small [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) [(175, 176)](#reference175). Since these studies have several limitations, including small sample size, additional research is warranted. Systemic lupus erythematosus More [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) and severe in non-Caucasian populations (Hispanics, African descendants, and Asians) [(177)](#reference177), [systemic lupus erythematosus](../glossary#systemic-lupus-erythematosus) (SLE) is an [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) with [heterogeneous](../glossary#heterogeneity) clinical manifestations. The disease can potentially affect most tissues and organs, including skin (skin rash and photosensitivity), kidneys (nephritis), and joints (arthritis). There is evidence of a role for vitamin D in the prevention of SLE in animal models [(178)](#reference178). Interestingly, a recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 11 [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) found that specific VDR [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) were linked to SLE in Asians particularly [(179)](#reference179). However, the functional relevance of such genetic variants is not known [(180)](#reference180). Analyses of two large [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of nearly 200,000 US women failed to show an association between dietary vitamin D intake (measured by [food frequency questionnaire](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire)) during adolescence or adulthood and incidence of SLE later in life [(168, 169)](#reference168). Yet, a suboptimal vitamin D status is commonly observed in subjects with SLE, and this is partly explained by the lack of sunlight exposure, which tends to aggravate disease symptoms [(181, 182)](#reference181). [Serum](../glossary#serum) concentrations of 25-hydroxyvitamin D were [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with measures of disease activity in a cohort of 378 patients with SLE [(183)](#reference183). The correction of vitamin D insufficiency with high levels of vitamin D3 (100,000 IU/week for one month followed by 100,000 IU/month for six months) in 20 subjects with SLE was linked to a reduction in signs of immune imbalance and in levels of autoantibodies typically detected in SLE, suggesting a therapeutic value for vitamin D in disease treatment [(184)](#reference184). Another prospective study conducted in 52 vitamin D-deficient patients with [cutaneous](../glossary#cutaneous) lupus erythematosus (a type of lupus with skin disorders only) reported a reduction in disease severity in the group [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) with vitamin D3 (1,400 IU/day initially, followed by 800 IU/day) and [calcium](../minerals/calcium) for one year compared to untreated patients [(185)](#reference185). Supplementation with vitamin D3 (200 IU/day for one year) was also able to reduce the level of inflammatory [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine) in a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study conducted in 267 patients with SLE [(186)](#reference186). In another randomized, placebo-controlled trial, supplementation with vitamin D3 (50,000 IU/week for six months) improved SLE disease activity index (SLEDAI) and European Consensus Lupus Activity Measurement (ECLAM) scores, as well as some measures of fatigue in young adults with juvenile-onset SLE [(187)](#reference187). However, in two other recent studies, supplementation with vitamin D3 (weekly/monthly bolus doses equivalent to ~800 to 7,000 IU/day for 6 to 24 months) improved vitamin D status in SLE patients but failed to show any benefit regarding disease activity [(188, 189)](#reference188). While oral vitamin D administration to SLE patients is well tolerated, its efficacy remains questionable and deserves further investigation in [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial). Summary Thus, evidence from human [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) suggests that while it cannot yet be concluded that vitamin D supplementation is beneficial in prevention or treatment of [autoimmune disease](../glossary#autoimmune-disease), it is reasonable to assume that correcting vitamin D insufficiency and maintaining sufficient levels could possibly help decrease disease [risk](../glossary#risk) [(190)](#reference190). Cardiovascular disease Hypertension (high blood pressure) [Hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) well-known [risk](../glossary#risk) factor for [observational](../glossary#observational-study) and [clinical studies](../glossary#clinical-trial) suggest a role for vitamin D in lowering blood pressure, which may be partly explained by the fact that 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D inhibits renin [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) (see [Function](#function)). Thus, vitamin D deficiency and subsequent upregulation of the renin-angiotensin system may contribute to high blood pressure and CVD risk. It has also been suggested that elevated PTH concentrations may increase the risk of [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) and CVD [(6)](#reference6). Yet, in a recent [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) of 3,002 individuals (mean age, 59 years at baseline), the incidence of hypertension, which affected 41% of participants during the nine year follow-up period, was not higher in those with [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations lower than 20 ng/mL and was only marginally associated with elevated PTH concentrations [(192)](#reference192). Nevertheless, a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven prospective studies, including a total of 48,633 participants with nearly 5,000 incident hypertension cases, found a 30% lower risk of hypertension in those in the top versus bottom [tertiles](../glossary#tertile) of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations. The dose-response analysis estimated that every 10 ng/mL increase in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was associated with a 12% lower risk of hypertension [(193)](#reference193). Another meta-analysis of four prospective and 14 [cross-sectional studies](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) also reported an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between and hypertension [(194)](#reference194). Endothelial dysfunction [Vascular endothelium](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction, contributes to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of [cardiovascular disease](../glossary#cardiovascular-disease) (CVD), is common in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) [(195)](#reference195). In CKD patients, abnormal endothelial function is associated with low values of flow-mediated dilation (FMD) of the brachial artery, a surrogate marker of vascular health. In a recent study conducted in subjects with mild-to-moderate CKD, serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations were positively associated with FMD values, suggesting a link between suboptimal vitamin D status and endothelial dysfunction [(196)](#reference196). In a preliminary [intervention study](../glossary#intervention-trial), 26 patients with moderate CKD and vitamin D insufficiency (mean value, 17.2 ng/mL) were supplemented twice with 300,000 IU of vitamin D3 (at weeks 1 and 8) and followed for a total of 16 weeks. Vitamin D supplementation nearly doubled [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and decreased PTH concentrations by 68.5%; improved vitamin D status was accompanied by increased FMD values and reduced levels of endothelial dysfunction markers [(197)](#reference197). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 12 small [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) in participants at high risk for CVD found a significant increase in FMD with vitamin D supplementation (daily doses, 2,500-5,000 IU; weekly dose, 50,000 IU; monthly dose, 60,000 IU; single-bolus doses, 100,000-200,000 IU) for eight weeks to six months [(198)](#reference198). Cardiovascular events in observational studies and clinical trials To date, the many [epidemiological studies](../glossary#epidemiological-study) investigating the relationship between vitamin D and outcomes of CVD have provided mixed results (reviewed in [199](#reference199)). Recent [Mendelian randomization studies](../glossary#Mendelian-randomization-study) found no association between genetically low [serum](../glossary#serum) D concentrations and [risks](../glossary#risk) of disease, or suggesting that associations reported in may be due to [confounding](../glossary#confounder) or [reverse causation](../glossary#reverse-causation). In the RECORD trial in 5,292 older people (see [Osteoporosis](#osteoporosis-prevention)), supplementation with 800 IU/day of vitamin D3 (± calcium) reduced the risk of first cardiac failure but had no effect on the risk of myocardial infarction and [stroke](../health-disease/stroke) compared to supplementation with calcium alone or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) [(202)](#reference202). Data on the effect of vitamin D supplementation on cardiovascular events were collected from 21 [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) (including the RECORD trial) in 13,033 participants (60 years old) and combined in a [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) [(202)](#reference202). No effect of vitamin D (including vitamin D [analogs](../glossary#analog)) was found for major [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) events, including [heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure), myocardial infarction, and stroke over follow-up periods of 1 to 6.2 years [(202)](#reference202). However, caution is advised when interpreting these results since the trials were initially designed to evaluate the effect of vitamin D on bone health, and cardiovascular outcomes were not primary endpoints. Several randomized controlled trials exploring the effect of vitamin D supplementation on CVD risk are currently underway [(203)](#reference203), including two large trials, the Vitamin D and Omega-3 Trial (VITAL) in the US [(204)](#reference204) and the D-Health trial in Australia [(205)](#reference205). The results of one randomized controlled trial, the Vitamin D Assessment (ViDA) trial in New Zealand, were recently published. The total number of CVD events and time to first CVD event during follow-up did not differ between those supplemented with vitamin D3 (initial dose of 200,000 IU for the first month followed by monthly doses of 100,000 IU) and those given a placebo for a median 3.3 years [(206)](#reference206). Type 2 diabetes mellitus People with [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) are at increased [risk](../glossary#risk) [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension), [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), and [obesity](../glossary#obesity). A recent study found that the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of type 2 diabetes was associated with low levels of [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D (<30 ng/mL) in 1,801 patients with metabolic During an eight-year follow-up period, lower risks of all-cause mortality (72% lower risk) and CVD-specific mortality (64% lower risk) were reported in individuals with serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations over 30 ng/mL (75 nmol/L) when compared to those with concentrations below 10 ng/mL (25 nmol/L) [(207)](#reference207). In healthy people, vitamin D sufficiency is positively correlated with [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) and adequate [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) -cell function. Conversely, vitamin D deficiency might affect [glucose](../glossary#glucose) [homeostasis](../glossary#homeostasis) and cause [impaired glucose tolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance) and insulin resistance [(208)](#reference208). In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) conducted in 12,719 adults, of whom 4,057 had prediabetes (i.e., an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes), the prevalence of prediabetes was associated with lower concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (32.4 ng/mL). Subjects with the lowest concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (17.7 ng/mL) were more likely to be current smokers, obese, and have hypertension [(209)](#reference209). Vitamin D insufficiency in high-risk individuals may accelerate the progression to overt diabetes. In a prospective study of 2,378 middle-aged men and women followed for 8 to 10 years, the risk for progression to type 2 diabetes from prediabetes was 62% lower in women and 60% lower in men in the highest compared to the lowest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of circulating vitamin D (>28.4 ng/mL vs. <18.5 ng/mL). A dose-response analysis measured an average 23% reduction in the risk of progression to type 2 diabetes for every 4 ng/mL (10 nmol/L) increment in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration [(210)](#reference210). A recent review and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 18 [prospective cohort studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), including over 210,000 participants followed for a median period of 10 years, found that individuals in the top third of vitamin D levels (reported as either circulating vitamin D or dietary intakes) had lower risks of developing type 2 diabetes (19% lower risk) and metabolic syndrome (14% lower risk) compared to those in the bottom third [(211)](#reference211). In another meta-analysis of nine prospective studies, including 28,258 older people (mean age, 67.7 years), lower versus higher circulating vitamin D concentrations at baseline were found to be associated with a 17% higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes over a median follow-up period of 7.3 years [(212)](#reference212). Currently, limited evidence suggests that vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) may improve insulin sensitivity in individuals with glucose intolerance or manifest type 2 diabetes [(213-216)](#reference213). There is a need for well-designed [clinical trials](../glossary#clinical-trial) to examine whether maintaining adequate vitamin D levels can prevent adverse metabolic outcomes in healthy and at-risk individuals. Neurodegenerative diseases Cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease [Alzheimer's disease](../health-disease/alzheimer-disease) (AD) is the most common form of [dementia](../glossary#dementia), characterized by the presence of extra- [neuronal](../glossary#neuron) - [amyloid and intra-neuronal Tau [protein](../glossary#protein) aggregates (known as neurofibrillary tangles) in the brain. Mechanistic models currently investigated in animal research suggest that vitamin D deficiency or disorders of vitamin D [metabolism](../glossary#metabolism) and/or the disruption of the vitamin D-VDR pathway in the [cerebral](../glossary#cerebral) regions of the cortex and hippocampus may be involved in the degeneration of [neurons](../glossary#neuron) and loss of [cognitive](../glossary#cognitive) functions [(217)](#reference217). Experimental evidence supporting a role for vitamin D in calcium channel regulation, neuroprotection, and immunomodulation in the [central nervous system](../glossary#central-nervous-system) also implies that low vitamin D status may precede or contribute to cognitive dysfunction with age [(218)](#reference218). A number of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined cognitive decline and degenerative brain disease in the elderly in relation to dietary intake of vitamin D and [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration. In a large French cohort study on [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) and hip [fractures](../glossary#fracture) in postmenopausal women, impairments in global cognitive performance, assessed with the Pfeiffer Short Portable Mental State Questionnaire (SPMSQ), were associated with lower dietary intakes of vitamin D (<1,400 IU/week vs. 1,400 IU/week) in 5,596 elderly women (mean age, 80.5 years) [(219)](#reference219). A seven-year follow-up study of a subgroup of 498 women indicated that the [risk](../glossary#risk) of Alzheimer's disease (but not other types of dementia) was 77% lower in those in the highest versus the lowest [quintiles](../glossary#quintile) of vitamin D dietary intakes at baseline [(220)](#reference220). Some, but not all, observational studies have found an association between low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and mild cognitive impairment in older adults [(219, 221, 222)](#reference219). The [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) and longitudinal analysis of two [prospective studies](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study), which included 1,604 men [(223)](#reference223) and 6,257 women [(224)](#reference224) aged 65 and over, reported a 60% greater odds of cognitive impairment at baseline and a 58% increased risk of cognitive decline during a four-year follow-up period in women, but not in men, with vitamin D deficiency (circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D <10 ng/mL vs. 30 ng/mL). In the [nested case-control](../glossary#nested-case-control-study), multiethnic, Singapore Kidney Eye Study, which included 2,273 individuals (mean age, 70.4 years), serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations were [inversely correlated](../glossary#inverse-association) with cognitive deficits affecting retrograde episodic memory, semantic memory, and orientation in time, as assessed by the Abbreviated Mental Test (AMT) [(225)](#reference225). Yet, [systematic reviews](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) of observational studies have given mixed results regarding the association of vitamin D status with cognitive performance and AD [(226-230)](#reference226). Moreover, the recent analysis of data from 1,182 men followed for 18 years in the Uppsala Longitudinal Study of Adult Men (ULSAM) failed to find associations of genetic determinants of vitamin D synthesis, vitamin D intakes, and [plasma](../glossary#plasma) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations with risks of cognitive impairments, AD, vascular dementia, or all-cause dementia [(231)](#reference231). In contrast, another [Mendelian randomization study](../glossary#Mendelian-randomization-study) associated genetic determinants of low vitamin D status to higher risk of AD in the International Genomics of Alzheimer's Project dataset (17,008 AD cases and 37,154 healthy cases) [(232)](#reference232). Nevertheless, the [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of vitamin D insufficiency/deficiency ranges between 70% and 90% in older adults, and correcting low concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D may help improve cognitive processes, in particular [executive functions](../glossary#executive-function) [(233)](#reference233). In a small, non-randomized controlled study in an outpatient clinic, global cognitive function was assessed at baseline and after 16 months in 20 patients [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) with 800 IU/day (or 100,000 IU/month) of vitamin D and in 24 control subjects. The supplementation of outpatients with vitamin D resulted in the correction of low vitamin D status (average serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was 16.8 ng/mL at baseline and 30 ng/mL at 16 months) and was associated with a significantly improved scoring in cognition tests compared to the non-supplemented group [(234)](#reference234). In a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled 32 mild-to-moderate AD patients receiving nasal [insulin](../glossary#insulin), high doses of vitamin D2 supplementation for eight weeks (up to 36,000 IU/day) did not significantly improve cognitive performance compared to low doses (1,000 IU/day) [(235)](#reference235). More research is needed to investigate a causal relationship between vitamin D [repletion](../glossary#replete) and potential long-term cognitive benefits in older adults. Further, it is of great importance to evaluate whether correcting vitamin D deficiency in cognitively impaired subjects can improve the impact of anti-dementia therapy [(236)](#reference236). Parkinson's disease [Parkinson's disease](../glossary#parkinson-disease) (PD) has been associated with a high [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of vitamin D insufficiency among patients, especially those with greater mobility problems [(237)](#reference237). A [case-control study](../glossary#case-control-study) of 296 outpatients with a mean age of 65 years indicated that 23% of PD subjects had [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations lower than 20 ng/mL compared to 16% and 10% of AD and healthy individuals, respectively [(238)](#reference238). In a [prospective cohort study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) conducted among 3,173 men and women aged 50-79 years and free of PD at baseline, individuals in the highest [quartile](../glossary#quartile) of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (20 ng/mL for women and 22.8 ng/mL for men) had a 67% lower risk of PD compared to those in the lowest quartile (10 ng/mL for women and 11.2 ng/mL for men) [(239)](#reference239). [Meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) pooling data from [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) all showed that vitamin D inadequacy was more likely reported in subjects with PD than in healthy controls [(240-242)](#reference240). In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, 112 PD patients (mean age, 72 years) on standard PD treatment were [supplemented](../glossary#supplement) with 1,200 IU/day of vitamin D or a placebo for 12 months. Vitamin D supplementation nearly doubled serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration (from mean of 22.5 ng/mL to 41.7 ng/mL) in supplemented subjects and limited the progression of PD, as indicated by a greater proportion of patients who showed no worsening (as assessed by the Hoehn and Yahr stage and the United Parkinson Disease Rating Scale part II) in the supplemented group compared to the placebo group [(243)](#reference243). It is not known whether vitamin D insufficiency has a role in the [pathogenesis](../glossary#pathogenesis) of the disease, but the [repletion](../glossary#replete) of vitamin D may provide health benefits that go beyond the prevention and/or the treatment of PD. For example, vitamin D deficiency may contribute to the increased risk of [osteoporosis](../glossary#osteoporosis) and bone [fracture](../glossary#fracture) in individuals with [neurologic](../glossary#neurologic) disorders, including PD and [multiple sclerosis](../glossary#multiple-sclerosis) [(244-246)](#reference244). Interestingly, sunlight exposure was found to be associated with improved vitamin D status, higher [bone mineral density](../glossary#bone-mineral-density) of the second metacarpal bone, and lower incidence of hip fracture in a prospective study conducted in 324 elderly people with PD [(247)](#reference247). Adverse pregnancy outcomes A [systematic review](../glossary#systematic-review) and [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 31 [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) on maternal vitamin D status and pregnancy outcomes indicated that vitamin D insufficiency may be associated with [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus), [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), and [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) vaginosis in pregnant women. Low maternal serum vitamin D during pregnancy was also linked to an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) for small-for-gestational age infants and low-birth-weight infants, but not for Cesarean section [(248)](#reference248). However, the number of [intervention trials](../glossary#intervention-trial) is currently too limited to draw conclusions as to whether vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) during pregnancy might reduce the incidence of the above-mentioned adverse outcomes [(249)](#reference249). Gestational diabetes mellitus Abnormal [hyperglycemia](../glossary#hyperglycemia) due to [pancreatic](../glossary#pancreas) characterizes the onset of [gestational](../glossary#gestation) [diabetes mellitus](../glossary#diabetes-mellitus) (GDM) in pregnant women without known type 2 diabetes mellitus. This condition is associated with serious adverse maternal outcomes, including [preeclampsia](../glossary#preeclampsia), high [risk](../glossary#risk) of Cesarean delivery, and life-long increased risk of developing [metabolic syndrome](../glossary#metabolic-syndrome) and type 2 diabetes mellitus. GDM may also contribute to increased risks of fetal macrosomia (excessive birth weight), neonatal [hypoglycemia](../glossary#hypoglycemia), infant respiratory distress, and increased life-long risk for [glucose intolerance](../glossary#impaired-glucose-tolerance), type 2 diabetes mellitus, and [cardiovascular disease](../health-disease/cardiovascular-disease) the offspring (reviewed in [250](#reference250)). A recent [prospective study](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) conducted in 655 pregnant women found that the mean [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration during the first trimester of pregnancy was significantly lower in 54 women who developed incident GDM compared to the rest of the cohort (23 ng/mL vs. 25.4 ng/mL). After multiple adjustments for [confounding](../glossary#confounder) factors of vitamin D status and GDM risk (including overweight/obesity and prior history of type 2 diabetes and GDM), the study found each 7.5 ng/mL decrease in serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration during early pregnancy was associated with a 48% higher risk of developing GDM [(251)](#reference251). Low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (<29.4 ng/mL) during the second trimester of pregnancy were also associated with GDM incidence in a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study) of 118 women with GDM and 219 subjects [(252)](#reference252). Five [meta-analyses](../glossary#meta-analysis) [(248](#reference248), [253-256)](#reference253), including [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) of moderate-to-high quality, also reported that maternal serum vitamin D concentrations during pregnancy were [inversely related](../glossary#inverse-association) to the risk of developing GDM despite evidence of [bias](../glossary#bias) amongst studies, such as the use of different methods for serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D measurement, measures done in different trimesters, and different criteria to assess GDM (reviewed in [257](#reference257)). Further, evidence for the role of vitamin D in [glucose](../glossary#glucose) regulation during pregnancy was reported in a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial in 54 pregnant women diagnosed with GDM. The [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) with 50,000 IU of vitamin D3 twice during a six-week period (at day 1 and day 21) resulted in significantly lower fasting [plasma](../glossary#plasma) glucose and serum [insulin](../glossary#insulin) concentration, reduced [insulin resistance](../glossary#insulin-resistance), and improved [insulin sensitivity](../glossary#insulin-sensitive) compared to placebo [(258)](#reference258). This suggests that vitamin D deficiency may adversely affect glucose tolerance during pregnancy and contribute to the onset of GDM. Yet, the potential benefits of vitamin D supplementation in the prevention of glucose intolerance and GDM during pregnancy have not been assessed. A multicentered, [randomized controlled trial ](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial)(DALI) is ongoing in Europe to evaluate the effects of vitamin D and lifestyle interventions (healthy eating and physical activity) on the metabolic status of pregnant women at risk of GDM (inclusion criteria: pre-pregnancy BMI 29 kg/m2) [(259)](#reference259). Preliminary findings suggest that healthy eating and physical activity can help lower gestational weight gain, when compared to standard-of-care; however, these lifestyle changes are unlikely to reduce the risk of GDM among obese pregnant women [(260)](#reference260). The results regarding the effect of vitamin D supplementation in the DALI study are yet to be published. Health outcomes in offspring During pregnancy, increased [intestinal](../glossary#small-intestine) [calcium](../minerals/calcium) absorption and mobilization of calcium from the skeleton allows accretion of calcium within the fetal skeleton. Yet, [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) that examined the relationship between maternal vitamin D status and measures of fetal bone growth have not provided consistent results [(261, 262)](#reference261). In addition, recent data from the Maternal Vitamin D Osteoporosis Study (MAVIDOS) suggested no difference in whole-body bone mineral content (BMC) of newborns from mothers randomized to daily supplementation with either vitamin D3 (1,000 IU) or [placebo](../glossary#placebo) from <17 weeks' gestation until delivery [(263)](#reference263). Further, the [risk](../glossary#risk) of [fracture](../glossary#fracture) in Danish children ages 10 to 18 years was similar regardless of whether their mothers were exposed to extra vitamin D from [fortification](../glossary#fortification) during pregnancy [(264)](#reference264). While maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy effectively prevents the neonate's risk of vitamin D deficiency at birth [(265)](#reference265), there is little evidence that neonatal vitamin D status influences the risk of fracture later during childhood [(266)](#reference266). A few observational studies have given rather weak evidence in support of a relationship between maternal vitamin D sufficiency during pregnancy and incidence of respiratory conditions and allergies in children [(267)](#reference267). A [randomized controlled trial](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) found that the supplementation of 108 pregnant women in the third trimester (at week 27 of gestation until delivery) with either 800 IU/day or a bolus dose of 200,000 IU of vitamin D3 did not decrease the risk of wheezing, allergic rhinitis, food allergy diagnosis, lower respiratory tract infections, or eczema in offspring at three years of age compared to placebo (N=50) [(268)](#reference268). A more recent [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), randomized controlled trial found that vitamin D3 supplementation of 295 Danish pregnant women, from weeks 22 to 26 of gestation until delivery, with 2,800 IU/day (70 g/day) — compared to 400 IU/day (10 g/day) of vitamin D3 (i.e., the current recommendation in Denmark) (N=286) — reduced the risk of troublesome episodes of lung symptoms by 17% in offspring during the first three years of life [(269)](#reference269). However, no differences were reported regarding the risk of persistent wheeze, [asthma](../glossary#asthma), allergic sensitization, respiratory tract infections, or eczema between treatment and control groups [(269)](#reference269). In a similar randomized, double-blind, controlled trial — the Vitamin D Antenatal Asthma Reduction Trial — conducted in 777 US pregnant women with a history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema (or whose partner had such an history), supplementation with 2,400 IU/day (60 g/day) or 400 IU/day (10 g/day) did not result in differences in the risk of developing asthma or recurrent wheezing in their children at age three years [(270)](#reference270). Despite the lack of significance reported in individual studies, the pooled analysis of the three trials found a 19% reduction in the risk of recurrent wheeze in children whose mothers received high-dose versus low-dose vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy [(271)](#reference271). In a cohort of 378 mother-child pairs, high [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations measured in the 34th week of pregnancy were associated with an increase in food allergy of the child during the first two years of life, warranting careful evaluation of the safety of vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy [(272)](#reference272). Since vitamin D insufficiency has been linked to [autoimmunity](../glossary#autoimmune-disease) (see [Autoimmune diseases](#autoimmune-diseases-prevention)), it has also been proposed that poor maternal vitamin D status during pregnancy may contribute to an increased risk of autoimmune diabetes ( [insulin](../glossary#insulin)-dependent type 1 diabetes mellitus) in the offspring. Yet, the results of a study of 3,723 children at high genetic risk for type 1 diabetes and followed for a mean 4.3 year-period found that maternal intake of vitamin D (from food and/or supplements) during the third trimester of pregnancy (assessed through [food frequency questionnaires](../glossary#food-frequency-questionnaire)) was not associated with advanced -cell autoimmunity or clinical diabetes [(142)](#reference142). In a [nested case-control study](../glossary#nested-case-control-study), there was no difference in mean serum concentration of 25-hydroxyvitamin D during the first trimester of pregnancy between 343 mothers of children with type 1 diabetes and 343 control mothers [(143)](#reference143). A follow-up study suggested that specific maternal VDR polymorphisms, rather than vitamin D status, may be linked to an increased susceptibility to developing type 1 diabetes in children [(273)](#reference273).
