Another nested case-control study (119 mothers of children with type 1 diabetes and 129 control mothers) found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between maternal vitamin D-binding protein — but not 25-hydroxyvitamin D — concentration during the third trimester of pregnancy and the risk of type 1 diabetes in children [(274)](#reference274). At present, there is no established causality between maternal vitamin D status during pregnancy and risk of autoimmune disease in offspring. Acute respiratory infections More than 200 [viruses](../glossary#virus) are responsible for causing familiar infections of the upper respiratory tract (URT), known as the [common cold](../health-disease/common-cold), resulting in symptoms of nasal congestion and discharge, cough, sore throat, and sneezing [(275)](#reference275). The analysis of [cross-sectional](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) data from 18,883 participants (ages 12 years and older) of the Third US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III) reported an [inverse relationship](../glossary#inverse-association) between [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and recent (self-reported) URT infection (URTI). Compared to levels of circulating vitamin D of 30 ng/mL or above, the [risk](../glossary#risk) of URTI was 24% higher in individuals with concentrations between 10 and 29 ng/mL and 36% higher in those with levels below 10 ng/mL [(276)](#reference276). A subgroup analysis indicated that low concentrations of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D in subjects with [asthma](../glossary#asthma) and [chronic obstructive pulmonary disease](../glossary#chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease) (COPD) were linked to a greater susceptibility to URTI when compared to people without pulmonary disease. In a [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled trial conducted in 322 healthy adults (ages 18 years), supplementation with monthly doses of vitamin D3 (200,000 IU for the first two months and 100,000 IU for the following 16 months) significantly raised the mean serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration (from 29 ng/mL to 48 ng/mL) in the intervention group but did not decrease the occurrence of URTI compared to placebo [(277)](#reference277). Moreover, in a larger, multicenter, four-arm [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial) in 2,259 subjects (aged 45-75 history of [colorectal adenoma](../glossary#colorectal-adenoma), daily vitamin D3 supplementation of 1,000 IU did not reduce the number or the duration of URTI episodes during winter or the rest of the year, even among participants with the lowest serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations at baseline [(278)](#reference278). In addition, the post-hoc analysis of data from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 644 individuals (ages 60-84 years) found that monthly supplementation with 30,000 IU or 60,000 IU of vitamin D3 for a maximum period of one year did not significantly decrease the rate of antibiotic prescriptions for [bacterial](../glossary#bacteria) airway infections. The stratified analysis, however, found that doses of 60,000 IU/month reduced the risk of using antibiotics in participants 70 years old by 47% [(279)](#reference279). In addition, compared to placebo, the supplementation of pregnant women with vitamin D3 (with 2,000 IU/day) for three months until birth followed by the supplementation of their infants (800 IU/day) from birth to six months of age significantly reduced the number of acute respiratory infections after the intervention period in children 6 to 18 months old [(280)](#reference280). Interestingly, despite significant [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) among trials, the pooled analysis of these data with that of 21 additional trials suggested an overall 12% reduction in incidence of URTI with vitamin D3 given as bolus doses (every week, month, or every three months), daily doses, or a combination of bolus and daily doses [(281)](#reference281). Subgroup analyses revealed a 42% reduction in URTI risk with vitamin D3 supplementation in subjects with baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <10 ng/mL, while there was no protective effect of vitamin D3 in those with concentrations 10 ng/mL. Moreover, large bolus doses (30,000 IU) were found to be ineffective compared to daily or weekly doses such that, in subgroup analyses that excluded bolus doses, daily and weekly vitamin D3 regimens appeared to be protective against URTI regardless of baseline vitamin D status. Finally, the effect of vitamin D3 supplementation on URTI did not appear to vary with age, [BMI](../glossary#body-mass-index), the presence of asthma or COPD, and flu vaccination status [(281)](#reference281). The findings of a large clinical trial in New Zealand, the Vitamin D Assessment (ViDA) Study, confirmed the ineffectiveness of large bolus doses of vitamin D in reducing the risk of acute respiratory infections [(282)](#reference282). In this double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 5,110 older adults (ages 50-84 at baseline), supplementation with an initial dose of 200,000 IU of vitamin D3 followed by 100,000 IU/month of vitamin D3 for a median of 3.3 years had no effect on the incidence of (self-reported) acute respiratory infections (HR, 1.01; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval), 0.94-1.07). Upon data stratification by vitamin D status, a similar null result (HR, 1.08; 95% CI, 0.95-1.23) was seen in study participants with blood vitamin D concentrations 20 ng/mL (50 nmol/L; [282](#reference282)). The recently completed VITAL (Vitamin D and Omega-3 Trial) may provide additional evidence of an effect of daily dosing (2,000 IU/day of vitamin D) on risk of airway infections in older adults, although the prevention of infectious disease is a secondary outcome in the trial [(204](#reference204), [283, 284)](#reference283). In a trial in preschool-age children, vitamin D supplementation with 2,000 IU/day for at least four months did not decrease the incidence [(285)](#reference285) or severity [(286)](#reference286) of URTI in winter compared to supplementation with 400 IU/day for at least four months. Supplementation with 2,000 IU/day led to significantly higher mean serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations compared to the lower dose (48.7 ng/mL vs. 36.8 ng/mL), but the 400 IU dose may have been sufficient to prevent URTI in these young children [(285)](#reference285). In a placebo-controlled trial in 1,300 healthy children and adolescents in rural Vietnam (baseline 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations of 26 ng/mL for both the control and intervention group), supplementation with 14,000 IU/week of vitamin D for eight months significantly reduced the incidence of non-influenza viral respiratory infections by 24%, but not the incidence of influenza A or B infection [(287)](#reference287). Coronavirus disease, COVID-19 The coronavirus disease, COVID-19, is caused by infection with the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). This virus originated in Wuhan, China in late 2019 and rapidly spread throughout the world causing a global pandemic. Flu-like symptoms, including cough, fever, fatigue, and difficulty breathing, as well as several other diverse symptoms characterize COVID-19 (see the websites of the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html) and the [WHO](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public)). The effects of the disease vary widely, with the most severe resulting in pneumonia, respiratory distress, and death. Some individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2, however, are asymptomatic but can transmit virus to others [(288)](#reference288). Moreover, SARS-CoV-2 infected individuals can spread disease before they experience symptoms (i.e., presymptomatic transmission) [(289)](#reference289), placing importance on public health measures like hand washing, face mask wearing, social distancing, and testing and contact tracing to curtail the pandemic. A number of [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) have examined the correlation of vitamin D status and COVID-19 incidence, with most — but not all [(290-292)](#reference290) — finding vitamin D deficiency or insufficiency associated with an increased [risk](../glossary#risk) of SARS-CoV-2 infection. In a [retrospective](../glossary#retrospective-study) cohort study of more than 191,000 US residents administered a SARS-CoV-2 test during a three-month period in spring 2020, SARS-CoV-2 positivity was strongly associated with a lower [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration, measured at a single point in the 12 months prior to the viral test [(293)](#reference293). In this study, each 1 ng/mL increment of serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D was linked to a 1.6% lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 positivity, with the risk being the lowest at serum concentrations of 55 ng/mL and above [(293)](#reference293). In a retrospective, population-based study among 7,807 people in Israel, including 782 SARS-CoV-2 positive cases, [plasma](../glossary#plasma) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations below 30 ng/mL were associated with a 50% higher risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection compared to higher vitamin D concentrations [(294)](#reference294). The vitamin D status assessment in this study was done prior to the viral testing, but details on the time frame are lacking. The temporal relationship of the vitamin D status measure and COVID diagnostic test is also a concern in an analysis of a large dataset from the UK Biobank, which found vitamin D status was not associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection: the study utilized vitamin D status assessments done 10 to 14 years prior to the COVID-19 diagnostic test [(291)](#reference291). Consistent with findings of most available studies, a small retrospective cohort study [(295)](#reference295) and five [case-control studies](../glossary#case-control-study) [(296-300)](#reference296) reported an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) vitamin D status and SARS-CoV-2 infection. A 2021 [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 10 observational studies, including 361,934 participants, reported an association between vitamin D insufficiency or deficiency and increased risk of COVID-19 ( [OR](../glossary#odds-ratio), 1.43; 95% [CI](../glossary#confidence-interval): 1.00-2.05), although [heterogeneity](../glossary#heterogeneity) across studies was high [(301)](#reference301). Further, in an analysis of data from the UK Biobank, regular use of vitamin D supplements was found to be associated with a 34% lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection compared nonusers of vitamin D supplements [(292)](#reference292). Additionally, most of the available observational research suggests an association between low vitamin D status and COVID-19 severity, with studies finding vitamin D deficiency linked to an increased risk of disease severity, as measured by need for hospitalization, intensive care unit admission [(302)](#reference302), stage of pneumonia (in men but not in women; [303](#reference303)), need for non-invasive ventilation [(304)](#reference304), need for invasive mechanical ventilation [(305)](#reference305), or a combination of these and other indicators [(297)](#reference297). Another study found that insufficient vitamin D status, defined as plasma 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations below 30 ng/mL, was associated with an increased likelihood of COVID-related hospitalization, but the association failed to reach statistical significance (p=0.061) except in a subanalysis of individuals over 50 years of age (OR, 2.71; 95% CI: 1.55-4.78; p<0.001) [(294)](#reference294). In contrast to most of the evidence to date, one case-control study found vitamin D deficiency was not linked to COVID-19 severity [(298)](#reference298). Further, a few studies have looked at the relationship of vitamin D status and COVID-19 mortality, with three finding vitamin D deficiency to be associated with an increased risk of death [(303](#reference303), [305, 306)](#reference305) and two finding no association [(304](#reference304), [307)](#reference307), although one of the studies finding no association used vitamin D status measurements more than 10 years prior to the COVID-19 diagnostic testing [(307)](#reference307). Since there are several known risk factors for severe illness from COVID-19, including advanced age, obesity, and preexisting type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease [(308)](#reference308), it is important for observational studies to control for potential [confounders](../glossary#confounder). Two quasi-experimental studies reported that bolus supplementation with vitamin D3 (either 50,000 IU per month or 80,000-100,000 IU every two to three months) prior to or during SARS-CoV-2 infection was associated with a less severe illness and improved survival in frail elderly COVID-19 patients [(309, 310)](#reference309). A number of [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) of vitamin D supplementation in COVID-19 prevention and treatment are currently underway; the results of these trials will inform on the causality of the association. Nevertheless, the currently available data indicate that improving vitamin D status through supplementation represents a modifiable risk factor for COVID-19. Disease Treatment Atopic dermatitis Atopic dermatitis or eczema is particularly [prevalent](../glossary#prevalence) in industrialized countries, affecting 10%-20% of children and 1%-3% of adults. Atopic dermatitis is a chronic [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) skin disorder characterized by dry and pruritus (itchy) areas of the skin in affected subjects. Local skin inflammation and immune dysfunction can damage the [epidermal](../glossary#epidermis) barrier and increase the susceptibility to skin infections and atopic reactions in affected individuals. The disease is often associated with other atopic diseases, including food allergies, [asthma](../glossary#asthma), and allergic rhinitis [(311)](#reference311). While the [etiology](../glossary#etiology) of the disease is not fully elucidated, it has been suggested that vitamin D deficiency might contribute to the onset and/or the severity of the disease [(312)](#reference312). Recently, using large-scale datasets from Caucasian people of European descent, including the UK Biobank resource [(313)](#reference313) and the SUNLIGHT [(35)](#reference35), the GABRIEL asthma and EAGLE eczema [(315)](#reference315) consortia, a [Mendelian randomization study](../glossary#Mendelian-randomization-study) found no association between genetically low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations and [risks](../glossary#risk) of number of [randomized controlled studies](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) have examined whether vitamin D might be an effective [adjunct](../glossary#adjunct) tool in disease management, possibly through regulating local inflammatory reactions and stimulating [antimicrobial](../glossary#antimicrobial) activities in the skin. Moreover, the beneficial effect of phototherapy observed in specific cases of atopic dermatitis may be partly mediated by the action of vitamin D [(311)](#reference311). In a small [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study in 45 patients with atopic dermatitis and low vitamin D status (70% of subjects had serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <20 ng/mL), daily administration of 1,600 IU of oral vitamin D3, alone or together with 600 IU/day of [vitamin E](vitamin-E), for a period of 60 days significantly reduced the extent and intensity of eczema, as assessed by the SCORAD (SCORing Atopic Dermatitis) score [(317)](#reference317). Vitamin D3 (1,600 IU/day for 60 days) also improved vitamin D status and reduced disease severity in 53 patients with atopic dermatitis in another small randomized trial [(318)](#reference318). More recently, vitamin D3 (1,000 IU/day for one month) improved the severity of winter-related atopic dermatitis in Mongolian children, as shown by changes in Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) and Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) scores [(319)](#reference319). A [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of four small trials (including those cited above) confirmed that supplemental vitamin D can lead to measurable clinical improvements in affected individuals [(320)](#reference320). Larger trials are needed to strengthen these preliminary findings and determine the most appropriate and effective supplementation regimen. Of note, [topical](../glossary#topical) treatment of [psoriasis](../glossary#psoriasis) with vitamin D [analogs](../glossary#analog) has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and may be effective in the management of other skin disorders [(321)](#reference321). Inflammatory bowel diseases Several ill-defined environmental and genetic factors are thought to contribute to the development of the inappropriate immune response to the [intestinal microbiota](../glossary#intenstinal-microbiota) that causes [ulcerative colitis](../glossary#ulcerative-colitis) (UC) and [Crohn's disease](../glossary#crohn-disease) (CD). While specific VDR [polymorphisms](../glossary#polymorphism) may be linked to an increased susceptibility to developing UC and CD [(322)](#reference322), higher vitamin D intakes and predicted circulating levels were found to be associated with a reduced incidence of UC and CD in a large cohort of 72,719 women [(323)](#reference323). A meta-analysis of six [observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) found an [inverse association](../glossary#inverse-association) between vitamin D status and severity of CD [(324)](#reference324). Three studies have investigated whether vitamin D3 could benefit patients with CD, possibly through reducing intestinal [inflammation](../glossary#inflammation). In one multicenter, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, the relapse rate in CD patients in remission after one year of treatment was significantly lower in those supplemented daily with 1,200 IU of vitamin D3 and 1,200 mg of [calcium](../minerals/calcium) compared to those who received calcium alone (13% vs. 29%) [(325)](#reference325). In a second [pilot study](../glossary#pilot-study), incremental daily doses of vitamin D3, from 1,000 IU up to 5,000 IU, were administrated over a 24-week period to 18 CD patients in order to achieve circulating 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations >40 ng/mL. Although half of the patients failed to achieve 40 ng/mL, the mean 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was raised to 45 ng/mL (from a baseline mean of 16 ng/mL), and the overall improvement in vitamin D status was associated with a significant decrease in disease severity as assessed by Crohn's Disease Activity (CDAI) scores [(326)](#reference326). In a three-month, [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 27 CD patients in remission, daily supplementation with vitamin D3 (2,000 IU) improved vitamin D status but had no significant effect on intestinal permeability ('leaky gut') or measures of inflammation and disease activity [(327)](#reference327). Yet, the study suggested that achieving serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations 30 ng/mL might help reduce intestinal inflammation and improve patients' quality of life. Additional studies are needed to confirm the therapeutic efficacy of vitamin D in [inflammatory bowel diseases](../glossary#inflammatory-bowel-disease). Cardiovascular disease The [prospective](../glossary#prospective-cohort-study) analysis of 41,504 electronic medical records in the Intermountain Heart Collaborative study found that only one-third of patients had adequate [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations (>30 ng/mL); vitamin D insufficiency (serum D concentrations 30 ng/mL) was associated with increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) and incidence of many [cardiovascular](../glossary#cardiovascular) conditions, [(328)](#reference328). D status also been linked to arterial stiffness and [vascular endothelial](../glossary#vascular-endothelium) dysfunction — strong determinants of incident hypertension and adverse cardiovascular outcomes [(329)](#reference329). Hypertension Several [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have evaluated the effect of vitamin D [supplementation](../glossary#supplement) on blood pressure. An early controlled [clinical trial](../glossary#clinical-trial) in 18 men and women with untreated mild [hypertension](../glossary#hypertension) living in the Netherlands found that exposure to UVB radiation three times weekly for six weeks during the winter increased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations by 162%, lowered PTH concentrations by 15%, and decreased 24-hour ambulatory [systolic](../glossary#systolic-blood-pressure) and [diastolic blood pressure](../glossary#diastolic-blood-pressure) measurements by an average of 6 mm Hg [(330)](#reference330). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of 16 [randomized controlled trials](../glossary#randomized-controlled-trial) involving 1,879 participants, either healthy or with pre-existing cardiometabolic conditions (including hypertension), found no significant reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressures with vitamin D supplementation (800-8,571 IU/day for five weeks to one year). However, a subgroup analysis of six trials found a significant reduction of 1.31 mm Hg in diastolic blood pressure in individuals with preexisting conditions. While improvements in blood pressure may be expected in cases of vitamin D insufficiency/deficiency, the authors noted that suboptimal vitamin D status in participants was not exclusively observed in those with cardiometabolic conditions [(331)](#reference331). In contrast, in two recent intervention studies — the Styrian vitamin D hypertension trial [(332)](#reference332) and the Vitamin D therapy in individuals at high risk of hypertension trial [DAYLIGHT] [(333)](#reference333) — subjects with (pre)hypertension supplemented with vitamin D3 (400 to 4,000 IU/day for two to six months) showed no evidence of blood pressure lowering, regardless of their baseline vitamin D status (insufficient or adequate, according to the IOM's current cutoffs). Conditions that decrease vitamin D [synthesis](../glossary#synthesis) in the skin, such as having dark-colored skin, living in temperate latitudes, and aging, are associated with increased [prevalence](../glossary#prevalence) of hypertension [(334)](#reference334), suggesting that vitamin D may reduce blood pressure levels in selected groups of individuals. In the above-mentioned meta-analysis, one four-arm, [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled clinical trial was conducted in 283 African Americans randomized to receive daily vitamin D3 supplements of 1,000 IU, 2,000 IU, or 4,000 IU for a period of three months. Systolic blood pressure was decreased by 0.66 mm Hg with 1,000 IU/day, 3.4 mm Hg with 2,000 IU/day, and by 4 mm Hg with 4,000 IU/day while it increased by 1.7 mm Hg in the placebo group when compared to baseline. A significant reduction of 0.2 [mm Hg](../glossary#mm-Hg) in systolic blood pressure was detected per 1 ng/mL incremental increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration. However, there was no statistical difference on three-month change in blood pressure between vitamin D3 and placebo [(335)](#reference335). Another randomized, placebo-controlled study in 150 elderly participants (mean age, 77 years) showed that supplementation with 100,000 IU of vitamin D3 every three months for one year did not significantly lower blood pressure compared to placebo [(336)](#reference336). Further research is needed to determine whether vitamin D supplementation is helpful in the prevention or management of hypertension. Congestive heart failure [Congestive heart failure](../health-disease/heart-failure) (also called cardiac insufficiency) is characterized by increased heart rate and subsequent [hypertrophy](../glossary#hypertrophy) of the left heart [ventricle](../glossary#ventricles). Cardiac insufficiency is associated with a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), assessed by [echocardiography](../glossary#echocardiography). Inhibitors of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) (see [Blood pressure regulation](#blood-pressure-regulation)) are currently used as first-line therapy for patients with heart failure. In a [cross-sectional study](../glossary#cross-sectional-study) in healthy patients who underwent [coronary](../glossary#coronary-artery) angiography, [serum](../glossary#serum) 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations <30 ng/mL were associated with poorer coronary flow rates [(337)](#reference337). Suboptimal vitamin D status has also been linked to poorer [prognosis](../glossary#prognosis) in patients with heart failure [(338)](#reference338). Over the past several years, a number of [intervention studies](../glossary#intervention-trial) have examined the effect of vitamin D supplementation in those with cardiac insufficiency. In a 12-week [randomized](../glossary#randomized-design), [double-blind](../glossary#double-blind), [placebo](../glossary#placebo)-controlled study, daily supplementation with 1,200 IU of vitamin D3 in children with chronic congestive heart failure led to a significant increase in vitamin D status accompanied by an improved heart muscle performance (increased LVEF), as well as by lower levels of PTH and pro- [inflammatory](../glossary#inflammation) [cytokines](../glossary#cytokine) [(339)](#reference339). In another randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in 64 elderly patients with heart failure, participants receiving 800 mg/day of [calcium](../minerals/calcium) and 50,000 IU/week of vitamin D3 did not perform significantly better at physical performance tasks (used as proxy to assess aerobic capacity and skeletal muscle strength) compared to those supplemented with calcium only [(340)](#reference340). A recent [meta-analysis](../glossary#meta-analysis) of seven small randomized placebo-controlled trials in 573 subjects with heart failure showed that vitamin D supplementation (from 1,000 IU/day to 50,000 IU/week) for six weeks to nine months could reduce serum concentrations of PTH, tumor necrosis factor- (TNF-), and [C-reactive protein](../glossary#c-reactive-protein) (CRP). Yet, there were no differences in LVEF, circulating interleukin-10 (IL-10) concentration, and renin concentration between patients treated with vitamin D and those given a placebo [(341)](#reference341). Finally, in the EVITA (Effect of vitamin D on all-cause mortality) trial in patients with end-stage heart failure and inadequate vitamin D status (baseline serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D values, 8.6-19.7 ng/mL), supplementation with 4,000 IU/day for three years did not reduce the risk of mortality compared to placebo [(342)](#reference342). Sources Sunlight Solar ultraviolet-B radiation (UVB; wavelengths of 290 to 315 nanometers) stimulates the production of vitamin D3 in the [epidermis](../glossary#epidermis) of the skin [(343)](#reference343). Sunlight exposure can provide most people with their entire vitamin D requirement. Children and young adults who spend a short time outside two or three times a week will generally [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) all the vitamin D they need to prevent deficiency. One study reported that [serum](../glossary#serum) vitamin D concentrations following exposure to one [minimal erythemal dose](../glossary#minimal-erythemal-dose) of simulated sunlight (the amount required to cause a slight pinkness of the skin) to the whole body was equivalent to ingesting approximately 10,000 to 25,000 IU of vitamin D [(344)](#reference344). People with dark-colored skin synthesize markedly less vitamin D on exposure to sunlight than those with lighter complexion [(34)](#reference34). Additionally, older adults have diminished capacity to synthesize vitamin D from sunlight exposure and frequently use sunscreen or protective clothing in order to prevent skin [cancer](../glossary#cancer) and sun damage. The application of sunscreen with an SPF factor of 10 reduces production of vitamin D by 90% [(30)](#reference30). In latitudes around 40 degrees north or 40 degrees south (Boston is 42 degrees north), there is insufficient UVB radiation available for vitamin D synthesis from November to early March. Ten degrees farther north or south (Edmonton, Canada), the "vitamin D winter" extends from mid-October to mid-March. It has been estimated that up to 15 minutes of daily sun exposure on the hands, arms, and face around 12 pm throughout the year at 25 degrees latitude (Miami, FL) and during the spring, summer, and fall at 42 degrees (Boston, MA) latitude may provide a light-skinned individual with 1,000 IU of vitamin D [(345)](#reference345). Food sources Vitamin D is found naturally in only a few foods, such as some fatty fish (mackerel, salmon, sardines), fish liver oils, eggs from hens that have been fed vitamin D, and mushrooms exposed to sunlight or UV light. In the US, milk and infant formula are [fortified](../glossary#fortification) with vitamin D so that they contain 400 IU (10 g) per quart. However, other dairy products, such as cheese and yogurt, are not always fortified with vitamin D. Some cereal, bread, and fruit juices may also be fortified with vitamin D. Accurate estimates of average dietary intakes of vitamin D are difficult because of the high variability of the vitamin D content of fortified foods [(346)](#reference346). For more information on the nutrient content of specific foods, search [USDA's FoodData Central](https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/). Safety Toxicity Vitamin D toxicity (hypervitaminosis D) has not been observed to result from sun exposure. The reason is that excessive sunlight exposure generates a number of biologically inert photoproducts from 7-dehydrocholesterol and induces abnormally high [serum](../glossary#risk) [calcium](../minerals/calcium) concentration (hypercalcemia), which could result in bone loss, [kidney stones](../glossary#kidney-stones), and calcification of organs like the heart and kidneys if untreated over a long period of time. Hypercalcemia has been observed following daily doses of greater than 50,000 IU of vitamin D [(360)](#reference360). Overall, research suggests that vitamin D toxicity is very unlikely in healthy people at intake levels lower than 10,000 IU/day [(361-363)](#reference361). However, the Food and Nutrition Board of the IOM conservatively set the tolerable upper intake level ( [UL](../glossary#UL)) at 4,000 IU/day (100 g/day) for all adults (Table 3). Certain medical conditions can increase the [risk](../glossary#risk) of hypercalcemia in response to vitamin D, including primary [hyperparathyroidism](../glossary#hyperparathyroidism), sarcoidosis, [tuberculosis](../glossary#tuberculosis), and lymphoma [(361)](#reference361). People with these conditions may develop hypercalcemia in response to any increase in vitamin D nutrition and should consult a qualified health care provider regarding any increase in vitamin D intake. Hypercalcemia (Cardizem) in Institute Recommendation The Linus Pauling Institute recommends that generally healthy adults take 2,000 IU (50 g) of [supplemental](../glossary#supplement) vitamin D daily. Most multivitamins contain 400 IU (10 g) of vitamin D, and single-ingredient vitamin D supplements are available for additional supplementation. Sun exposure, diet, skin color, and [body mass index](../glossary#body-mass-index) (BMI) have variable, substantial impact on body vitamin D levels. To adjust for individual differences and ensure adequate body vitamin D status, the Linus Pauling Institute recommends aiming for a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration of at least 30 ng/mL (75 nmol/L). [Observational studies](../glossary#observational-study) suggest that serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations between 30 ng/mL and 60 ng/mL are associated with lower [risks](../glossary#risk) of adverse health outcomes, including [cancers](../glossary#cancer) and [autoimmune diseases](../glossary#autoimmune-disease). The American Academy of Pediatrics currently suggests that all infants, children, and adolescents receive 400 IU of supplemental vitamin D daily [(19)](#reference19). Consistent with the recommendations of the Endocrine Society [(40)](#reference40), the Linus Pauling Institute recommends daily intakes of 400 to 1,000 IU (10 to 25 g) of vitamin D in infants and 600 to 1,000 IU (15 to 25 g) of vitamin D in children and adolescents. Given the average vitamin D content of breast milk, infant formula, and the diets of children and adolescents, supplementation may be necessary to meet these recommendations. Older adults (>50 years) Daily supplementation with 2,000 IU (50 g) of vitamin D is especially important for older adults because aging is associated with a reduced capacity to [synthesize](../glossary#synthesis) vitamin D in the skin upon sun exposure.
